articles.headline: It Introduced Ozempic to the World. Now It Must Remake Itself.
articles.snippet: Novo Nordisk’s factories work nonstop turning out Ozempic and Wegovy, its blockbuster weight-loss drugs, but the Danish company has far bigger ambitions.
articles.abstract: Novo Nordisk’s factories work nonstop turning out Ozempic and Wegovy, its blockbuster weight-loss drugs, but the Danish company has far bigger ambitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lars Fruergaard Jorgensen has a problem: Too many people want what he’s selling.
articles.byline: By Eshe Nelson and Charlotte de la Fuente

articles.headline: A Ragtag Resistance Sees the Tide Turning in a Forgotten War
articles.snippet: Rebel fighters have handed Myanmar’s army defeat after defeat, for the first time raising the possibility that the military junta could be at risk of collapse.
articles.abstract: Rebel fighters have handed Myanmar’s army defeat after defeat, for the first time raising the possibility that the military junta could be at risk of collapse.
articles.lead_paragraph: The night Ma Suu Kyi thought she would die of her wounds on the front lines of a forgotten war, a crescent moon hung overhead. A pendant of the Virgin Mary dangled around her neck. Maybe those augurs saved her. Or maybe, she said, it was not yet time for her to die.
articles.byline: By Hannah Beech and Adam Ferguson

articles.headline: Top Chinese Swimmers Tested Positive for Banned Drug, Then Won Olympic Gold
articles.snippet: The case, involving multiple swimmers who seven months later won medals at the 2021 Games, prompted accusations of a cover-up and concerns over why antidoping regulators chose not to intervene.
articles.abstract: The case, involving multiple swimmers who seven months later won medals at the 2021 Games, prompted accusations of a cover-up and concerns over why antidoping regulators chose not to intervene.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twenty-three top Chinese swimmers tested positive for the same powerful banned substance seven months before the Tokyo Olympic Games in 2021 but were allowed to escape public scrutiny and continue to compete after top Chinese officials secretly cleared them of doping and the global authority charged with policing drugs in sports chose not to intervene.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Tariq Panja

articles.headline: Americans’ New TV Habit: Subscribe. Watch. Cancel. Repeat.
articles.snippet: Many more people are jumping from one streaming subscription to another, a behavior that could have big implications for the entertainment industry.
articles.abstract: Many more people are jumping from one streaming subscription to another, a behavior that could have big implications for the entertainment industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early last year, Josh Meisel and his wife wanted to watch a new buzzy Peacock drama, “Poker Face,” starring Natasha Lyonne.

articles.headline: You Finished I.V.F. and Want to Donate Embryos. Is There a Tax Benefit?
articles.snippet: Some people may consider donating embryos to researchers in light of Alabama’s I.V.F. ruling and in advance of other state actions. Would it be considered a charitable gift?
articles.abstract: Some people may consider donating embryos to researchers in light of Alabama’s I.V.F. ruling and in advance of other state actions. Would it be considered a charitable gift?
articles.lead_paragraph: The Alabama Supreme Court’s in vitro fertilization ruling this year, which held that frozen embryos should be considered children, raised a long list of questions for people worried about their future fertility treatments. My colleague Tara Siegel Bernard and I attempted to answer many of them in February.

articles.headline: House Approves $95 Billion Aid Bill for Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan
articles.snippet: After months of delay at the hands of a bloc of ultraconservative Republicans, the package drew overwhelming bipartisan support, reflecting broad consensus.
articles.abstract: After months of delay at the hands of a bloc of ultraconservative Republicans, the package drew overwhelming bipartisan support, reflecting broad consensus.
articles.lead_paragraph: The House voted resoundingly on Saturday to approve $95 billion in foreign aid for Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan, as Speaker Mike Johnson put his job on the line to advance the long-stalled aid package by marshaling support from mainstream Republicans and Democrats.

articles.headline: The Town at the Center of a Supreme Court Battle Over Homelessness
articles.snippet: A lawsuit by a group of homeless residents of a small Oregon town could reshape the way cities across the country deal with homelessness.
articles.abstract: A lawsuit by a group of homeless residents of a small Oregon town could reshape the way cities across the country deal with homelessness.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inside a warming shelter, Laura Gutowski detailed how her life had changed since she became homeless two and a half years ago in Grants Pass, a former timber hub in the foothills of southern Oregon.

articles.headline: Could the Union Victory at VW Set Off a Wave?
articles.snippet: Some experts say the outcome at a plant in Chattanooga, Tenn., may be organized labor’s most significant advance in decades. But the road could get rockier.
articles.abstract: Some experts say the outcome at a plant in Chattanooga, Tenn., may be organized labor’s most significant advance in decades. But the road could get rockier.
articles.lead_paragraph: By voting to join the United Automobile Workers, Volkswagen workers in Tennessee have given the union something it has never had: a factory-wide foothold at a major foreign automaker in the South.

articles.headline: Golden Visa Programs, Once a Boon, Lose Their Luster
articles.snippet: Spain is the latest European country to end its program, which brought in billions of euros from real estate investors seeking residency status but worsened a housing crisis for locals.
articles.abstract: Spain is the latest European country to end its program, which brought in billions of euros from real estate investors seeking residency status but worsened a housing crisis for locals.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Ana Jimena Barba, a young doctor, began working at a hospital in Madrid last year, she moved in with her parents half an hour outside the city until she could save enough to buy her own home. But when she started looking at houses in the same village, almost everything was priced at more than 500,000 euros.

articles.headline: How the Israel-Gaza Protests Could Hurt the Democratic Party
articles.snippet: In 1968, the Democratic National Convention was overshadowed by clashes between police and demonstrators.
articles.abstract: In 1968, the Democratic National Convention was overshadowed by clashes between police and demonstrators.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s a nightmare scenario for Democrats: Protesters disrupt their convention this summer; they clash with the police; chaos seems to take hold.

articles.headline: How Mike Johnson Got to ‘Yes’ on Aid to Ukraine
articles.snippet: Intelligence, politics and personal considerations converted the Republican speaker, who had largely opposed aid to Ukraine as a rank-and-file member, into the key figure pushing it through Congress.
articles.abstract: Intelligence, politics and personal considerations converted the Republican speaker, who had largely opposed aid to Ukraine as a rank-and-file member, into the key figure pushing it through Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: For weeks after the Senate passed a sprawling aid package for Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan, Speaker Mike Johnson agonized over whether and how the House would take up funding legislation that would almost certainly infuriate the right wing of his party and could cost him his job.

articles.headline: Trump’s Trial Challenge: Being Stripped of Control
articles.snippet: The mundanity of the courtroom has all but swallowed Donald Trump, who for decades has sought to project an image of bigness and a sense of power.
articles.abstract: The mundanity of the courtroom has all but swallowed Donald Trump, who for decades has sought to project an image of bigness and a sense of power.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Sir, can you please have a seat.”

articles.headline: U.S. Considers Imposing Sanctions on Israeli Military Unit
articles.snippet: Israeli leaders expressed alarm about the possible action by the Biden administration over rights violations in the West Bank.
articles.abstract: Israeli leaders expressed alarm about the possible action by the Biden administration over rights violations in the West Bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States is considering imposing sanctions on one or more Israeli battalions accused of human rights violations during operations in the occupied West Bank, according to a person familiar with the deliberations.
articles.byline: By Isabel Kershner, Adam Rasgon and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: The Chinese Site That Rewired Online Shopping
articles.snippet: Pinduoduo appeals to people seeking deals and “downgraded spending,” as consumer purchasing in China has slowed recently amid economic rockiness.
articles.abstract: Pinduoduo appeals to people seeking deals and “downgraded spending,” as consumer purchasing in China has slowed recently amid economic rockiness.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Pinduoduo, the Chinese discount shopping app, debuted nearly a decade ago, the tech giants Alibaba and JD.com dominated China’s e-commerce business.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Claire Fu

articles.headline: Israel Planned Bigger Attack on Iran, but Scaled It Back to Avoid War
articles.snippet: The strike on Iran on Friday was originally intended to be much broader in scope, but after intense pressure from allies, Israeli leaders agreed to ratchet it down.
articles.abstract: The strike on Iran on Friday was originally intended to be much broader in scope, but after intense pressure from allies, Israeli leaders agreed to ratchet it down.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israel abandoned plans for a much more extensive counterstrike on Iran after concerted diplomatic pressure from the United States and other foreign allies and because the brunt of an Iranian assault on Israel soil had been thwarted, according to three senior Israeli officials.
articles.byline: By Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley

articles.headline: Spurred by Teen Girls, States Move to Ban Deepfake Nudes
articles.snippet: Legislators in two dozen states are working on bills, or have passed laws, to combat A.I.-generated sexually explicit images of minors.
articles.abstract: Legislators in two dozen states are working on bills, or have passed laws, to combat A.I.-generated sexually explicit images of minors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Caroline Mullet, a ninth grader at Issaquah High School near Seattle, went to her first homecoming dance last fall, a James Bond-themed bash with blackjack tables attended by hundreds of girls dressed up in party frocks.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Uphold Local Bans on Homeless Encampments
articles.snippet: A majority of the justices appeared skeptical of courts wading into the thorny policy questions around when local governments can punish people for sleeping and camping outdoors.
articles.abstract: A majority of the justices appeared skeptical of courts wading into the thorny policy questions around when local governments can punish people for sleeping and camping outdoors.
articles.lead_paragraph: A majority of the Supreme Court appeared inclined on Monday to uphold a series of local ordinances that allowed a small Oregon city to ban homeless people from sleeping or camping in public spaces.
